item.description: Email: moshepol[at]mit[dot]edu Twitter LinkedIn Fun Fact: Some words are regular travelers, going on vacation abroad and returning with a new accent. Consider the Arabic dār al-ṣināʿa (literally, house of manufacture; a factory). It was borrowed into Latin around the middle of the previous millenium as arsana, eventually becoming the word we know in English as arsenal. Not quite a place of production, but a place for storage of weapons (“arsenal, n.

item.title: Moshe Poliak
item.description: I am a PhD student in Brain and Cognitive Sciences at MIT. My advisor is Ted Gibson. I study psycholinguistics, or what processes in the mind are involed in language production and comprehension. Specifically, I study how we use non-lexical properties of language in comprehension and production. Using the noisy channel framework, I investigate how expectations about the formof the utterance affects how we interpret it. I am also trying to figure out what exactly makes two utterances similar to each other, in speech and in writing, and how this depends on individual differences in linguistic background.

item.title: Resources
item.description: Grad School Applications My grad school application process was greatly facilitated by having access to amazing resources. As an undergrad at Harvard, I had access to influential professors both at Harvard and elsewhere, kind and knowledgeable grad student mentors, courses at other institutions, funding for travel and research, and so on. I am endlessly grateful to all those people who worked very hard to help me. At the same time, this underscores how much privilege I have and how much an uneven playing field grad school applications are.
